Posts.Title: Pregnancy after Stage IV diagnosis Jejik CAROLINE77

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2012 10:29PM - edited Jun 21, 2012 10:31PM by sandyv I had a chest ct scan in 12/2011 which showed bone cancer in spine then I had a bone scan which was totally negative but since ct scan was showing so much cancer actually stating blastic lesions in every visible bone  on ct scan they decided to do a pet scan....well pet scan of entire body was positive for metastatic cancer from skull entire spine, ribs, clavicles,sacrum hips upper femur. I know this may not help but I am just trying to say that apparently bone scans are not always right in some situations you may need to move up to a pet scan they are more sensitive  or were in my case. They did call my bone cancer innumerable microscopic lesions which apparently meant that I have them everywhere but are very small largest was 8mm but still all combined enough to cause severe back and bone pain. So if your not 100% convinced of your bone scan results ask for pet scan.
Posts.Title: Can bone mets be missed with regular CT and bone scans? foreverhopeful GoldenGirls

Posts.Content: May 3, 2012 04:20AM sandyv wrote: 43  1st diagnosis but had felt mass several  years prior and mamo stated negatve until age 43 then dx with mets to bone  12/2011 at age 57 after several years of being passed from dr to dr to find out what was causing back pain. 1st in family with breast cancer, I should have been a better advocate for myself both times. Now I trust no Dr and the new guidelines are totally ridiculous in my opinion. now I know I should have had an ultrasound after 1st mamo. When I was trying to find about back pain my tumor markers were elevated and never had been in all those years so I wnt to 2 different oncos although one ordered  PET SCAN THAT WAS PROMTLY DENIED BY MY INSURANCE both told me not to worry about them .I was then sent to rhuematolgist and cardiologist. My bone mets was an incidental finding fom a ct a pulmonary dr who thought back pain might be due to lungs. sorrr for the rambling answer to your simple question.

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2012 02:53AM sandyv wrote: How about those people  that get cancer of the lung , breast, bone , pancreas and even cirrohsis of the liver  diabetic  that didn't smoke, have a poor diet, drink etc and thought they were doing everything healthy...They too get all of these terminal illnessses? NO DR. should judge why they are there to treat. If patients decide not to follow a treatment plan should the Dr refuse to treat and if so how do they really know which patients were the ones that that smoke drink eat poorly etc. Sometimes people get terminal illnesses without any reason. Just my opinion. How many of us know someone who never smoked or drank alcohol but died because of lung cancer or liver failure and how many of us know people that do both to excess and live a long and healthy life till old age gets them?

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2012 01:56AM sandyv wrote: My 1st treatment was zometa  and I had flu like symptoms for 3 weeks 103 temp and extreme bone  pain. After that I have taken just a shot of Xgeva monthly with little or no side effects. So if you have a problem with Zometa try Xgeva and as someone else said it is just a shot but does the same thing as Zometa as far as I know.  Good luck cape Town

Posts.Content: May 9, 2012 06:59AM sandyv wrote: my opinion would be it can't qualify as pre existing unless you see a Dr for this problem prior to the effective date of your insurance at least that has been my experience as a person who does insurance billing for a DR's office. If you are that upset you can surely get an appointment with some Dr sooner than 30 days.Good luck hope it turns out to be nothing as serious as you must be thinking. Of course your insurance co. will ask for records from all your DR's to see if it is pre existing that is always a constant problem before they pay us espesially for any newly insured patient.
